newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Anti-Taleban forces battle for Bagram airbase.
newsitem.headline: Anti-Taleban forces battle for Bagram airbase.

text.p: Forces loyal to former government commander Ahmad Shah Masood are battling for a big airbase north of Kabul after gaining ground from the fundamentalist Taleban militia, a military source said on Saturday.

The source, who asked not to be named, said Masood's guerrillas had launched a major attack on Thursday, driving the Taleban out of the key town of Jabal-os-Siraj, 70 km (44 miles) north of Kabul, and were now fighting for the Soviet-built Bagram airbase, 50 km (31 miles) from the capital.
The source said the Taleban had repulsed an assault on Bagram on Friday, but fighting was continuing.
He said Masood's forces had advanced southwards along the road from Jabal-os-Siraj and were fighting for control of a damaged bridge at Pul-i-Matak, north of the town of Charikar.
Masood captured Jabal-os-Siraj about two weeks ago, cutting off a Taleban force that had crossed the Salang Pass through the Hind Kush mountains into opposition-held northern Afghanistan.

The Taleban fought back, but were unable to reopen the pass to resupply their comrades, who were driven from their last foothold in the north when the town of Pul-i-Khumri fell to opposition forces on Wednesday.
